Prev         Up         Next

Process objects

Process objects represent activity that is run in a separate process.

The Process class is defined in the processing.process module but is also directly available from processing.

Process

The Process class is almost a clone of threading.Thread. The methods are

__init__(group=None, target=None, name=None, args=(), kwargs={})

This constructor should always be called with keyword arguments. Arguments are:

group
should be None; exists for compatibility with threading.Thread.
target
is the callable object to be invoked by the run() method. Defaults to None, meaning nothing is called.
name
is the process name. By default, a unique name is constructed of the form 'Process-N1:N2:...:Nk' where N1,N2,...,Nk is a sequence of integers whose length is determined by the 'generation' of the process. [1]
args
is the argument tuple for the target invocation. Defaults to ().
kwargs
is a dictionary of keyword arguments for the target invocation. Defaults to {}.

If a subclass overrides the constructor, it must make sure it invokes the base class constructor (Process.__init__()) before doing anything else to the process.

start()

Start the process's activity.

This must be called at most once per process object. It arranges for the object's run() method to be invoked in a separate process. [2]

run()

Method representing the process's activity.

You may override this method in a subclass. The standard run() method invokes the callable object passed to the object's constructor as the target argument, if any, with sequential and keyword arguments taken from the args and kwargs arguments, respectively.

join()

Wait until the process terminates. This blocks the calling thread until the process whose join() method is called terminates. [3]

A process can be joined many times.

A process cannot join itself because this would cause a deadlock.

It is an error to attempt to join a process before it has been started.

getName()
Return the process's name.
setName(name)

Set the process's name. [4]

The name is a string used for identification purposes only. It has no semantics. Multiple processes may be given the same name. The initial name is set by the constructor.

getAuthKey()

Return the process's authentication key (a string).

When the processing package is initialized the main process is assigned a random hexadecimal string produced using os.urandom().

When a Process object is created it will inherit the authentication key of its parent process, although this may be changed using setAuthKey() below.

See Authentication Keys. [5]

setAuthKey(value)

Set the process's authentication key which must be a string or None.

If value is None then a new key is automatically generated. [5]

Note

Unlike thread objects, process objects do not have methods isAlive(), isDaemon() or setDaemon().

[1]The default names of thread objects instead take the form 'Thread-N' where N is an integer.
[2]start() calls either os.fork() or os.spawnv() depending on the platform.
[3]Unlike Thread.join() this method does not support an optional timeout argument.
[4]Calling the setName() method of a process object from one process will not effect the name by which that process is known to any other started processes.
[5](1, 2) Thread objects do not have getAuthKey() and setAuthKey() methods.

Example

The following program prints 'Hello Bob' from a child process:

from processing import Process

def f(name):
    print 'Hello', name

if __name__ == '__main__':
    p = Process(target=f, args=['Bob'])
    p.start()
    p.join()

See Programming guidelines for an explanation of why the if __name__ == '__main__': test is needed on Windows.
